name: BBCWorld
text:
Five scientific institutions are joining forces to preserve the world‚Äôs largest aquatic frog üê∏

The endangered Lake Titicaca giant frog lives in the waters of its namesake and nearby lagoons, straddling the border between Peru and Bolivia üåé

[Thread]

https://t.co/SGwK2nj7xT

name: BBCWorld
text:
The frog is threatened by mining pollution and its use in traditional medicine

Scientists will study its habitat and carry out genetic analysis to find out how to best protect the species üî¨

https://t.co/SGwK2nj7xT https://t.co/SWW65VBkfZ

name: BBCWorld
text:
Known for its loose, baggy skin that folds around the body, it has earned the nickname ‚Äúscrotum frog‚Äù üê∏

Scientists think the skin flaps help the frogs absorb more oxygen in the lake's water, which is 12,500ft (4,000m) above sea level üåä

https://t.co/SGwK2nj7xT https://t.co/JpGxOfYPaL

name: BBCWorld
text:
In 2016, thousands of the frogs were found dead on the shores of a tributary to the lake 

Pollution from agriculture and plastics were thought to have caused the deaths üå´

https://t.co/SGwK2nj7xT https://t.co/q61DEnOe3j

name: BBCWorld
text:
They‚Äôre caught and used - mistakenly - as an aphrodisiac

The frogs are mixed into a drink called ‚Äúfrog juice‚Äù and sold at local markets

Their bodies are also used as amulets, and their skin is sometimes turned into small bags and their legs eaten

https://t.co/SGwK2nj7xT https://t.co/iTc7qd7hNE

name: BBCWorld
text:
